transcripts.text: Today on Cosmic Disclosure, we have Sergeant Clifford Stone, ex-military person who has been involved with extraterrestrials.  Sergeant Stone, welcome to the show today.
Thank you, sir.  Once again, it's my great pleasure to be here.
In your experience, have you ever been exposed to the inside of an extraterrestrial craft?
There were times that I had to go inside the craft itself.
What was that like?

It was scary.  You never knew what to expect.  No two events were exactly identical and you never knew what to look for.  I'd have to go in and from time to time the guy I always called the colonel would have me doing things.  I wasn't a mechanic.  I had no technical knowledge of anything.  And one thing I want to make clear from the get-go, in each instance, every crap we went into, because on sci-fi movies, you know, it looks like they hadn't been doing their house clean.  They were like clinically clean, like you were in a surgical room.  They didn't have cobwebs, things of this sort.  But the situation is that you go in there and, you know, you've just entered another reality.  I mean, here it is, we have a craft.  35-foot diameter on the outside.  This would have been in 1986, I believe.  We went in, and there were several instances like this, but it never ceases to amaze you.  30, 35-foot diameter on the outside, and you're awed when you go in there because you're thinking, okay, something's not right here.  Because it looks much bigger on the inside, but how can that be?  It's only 30, 35 foot diameter on the outside.  It couldn't be any bigger than that.  And it definitely couldn't be bigger than that on the inside.  But when you go in, I can explain it now, but it's hard for people to understand.  It was hard for me to understand when I first heard about it.  But then you'd go ahead and look up because, I mean, it was only maybe, what, 12 feet high, things of this sort.  Yet here it is.  This was maybe, I don't know, 40, 50 foot tall on the inside.  And I'm wondering, how can this be?  So we would go ahead and measure that.  The interesting thing, you saw no lights, but it was perfectly bright on the inside, not overlit, not underlit.  You had no problem seeing.  But then, you know, here it is.  Remember, we're working, and I have to stress this, 30, 35 foot in diameter.  But then you have, like, ladders.  that go up on several levels, maybe I think three, I'm going to say three, it could have been more, but at least three levels.  Then you'd have little walkways there, and you'd have compartments there.  that, you know, people are entities, and I'm sorry, I still consider them to be people within their own right.  that would go in there.  I don't know where they were living quarters, what they were actually there for, but they served a purpose, but there were rooms on board the craft.
Was there a type of cockpit or chair or anything like that?

There was a control department compartment, which they obviously had, the way I remember it, there was like a control panel.  there was two seats in front, there was a seat in back, and on back over, where the entrance was, on each side, there was a seat there.  Now, the control panels was unique in that they didn't have, like, you know, on board a fighter aircraft, you have a control stick.  It was like I know this now, but it was just the impression at the time that they were controlling with the instruments they had by just putting their hands over it or moving them over it, and they could control the craft that way.  And the whole situation is they could program the craft to be like on automatic pilot by certain motions of the hand.  And there was also an avoidance system where they wouldn't crash into one another.  They would get real close to aircraft, our aircraft, but just before there'd be a collision, they would immediately go ahead and break off from making contact with the aircraft.  They had other rooms that looked like there was some type of... things going on within these other, like they were electronic components of something that they were working with.  I have no idea what they were.  You also had areas that looked like they were living quarters.  because they had like cots there, things of that sort.  And I'm using the wrong word, cots, because, you know, not like on a submarine is the best way to put it.  They also had, I guess, where they would go and change into various types of clothing that they would have to wear to do certain functions.  They had all of that there.  But here again... where you'd go ahead and expect to find trash cans where they'd have trash put into them.  Mm-mm.  Trash on the floor.  Mm-mm.  I mean, they were just so clinically It's hard to describe it.
What kind of clothing and what did it look like?
Well, they had different colors like white, they had yellow, they had red.
Were they two-piece, three-piece, ten-piece?
They all looked like one piece.  And once again, how did they get into them?  And it looked like one size fit all.  That was the opinion that I had.
One fascinating thing I learned from you, you mentioned a propulsion unit.

Not with this craft, because I didn't have to go to it.  We went on one craft, and the craft was, you know, it was like a small, the engine, the proportion unit, was like a matchbox, small as a matchbox.  And trying, you know, I turned to the guy I always called the Colonel, this can't be the proportion unit, this might be a component, but how are you going to get a craft this big to go as fast as it was going on this
small, little,
and it was rectangular.
And this is before you realized size did not matter in this field of science.
Oh, absolutely.

I believe also through my experience, when being on these craft, and they're still only when they're on, that it has their own gravitational field around them, which means they're actually in their own space.  So when you walk on there, now you're in their space, and it could be as big as the Empire State Building inside, but look on the outside, as big as a bowling ball.

Oh, absolutely.  I mean, I hesitate to bring this up, but it's a key point.  And I'm not a scientist.  I can't explain it.  But a lot of times you may have a craft.  that to us would be maybe a little bigger than this.  But yet, you and I could walk around and have plenty of space on the inside.  You're working multidimensional within the craft itself, but it's all interconnected.  And I don't know how to explain that.  It's hard to describe.  It's hard to put into words.  Like in this instance, I'm a layperson.  I know what I saw.  I can try to put it into words to articulate what it was I saw, but it's hard to do.
Were there other people there with you when you came?
Oh, absolutely.
What was your team made up of?

Now, with my team, we had maybe 15 to 20 people on each of the NBC teams.  But you could draw up on the resources of the nearest military installation, which we did quite frequently because our team was specifically geared to do certain things, each member of our team.  We would draw up on other resources to go ahead, maybe for other vehicles and drivers to move some of the stuff that we wanted to move, some of the debris, even up to and including the whole craft at times, but also to provide perimeter security for where the object was because we did not want people coming in and ask questions about why we were there and what we were doing.
Did you see any language on board?

I saw things, but it wasn't like English or anything like that.  They actually looked like, and the best thing I can do is say like.  they were hieroglyphics, and that may not even be the appropriate term, but they were symbols.  But I knew right from the beginning this was like us writing English.  This was their language.  And to them, they knew how to read it, and they were explaining certain things in their language for their people.  And they had even what you'd consider desks.  Well, I thought to be writing instruments.  They definitely didn't look like ink pens, but they were writing instruments.  It was a little thing that if you went and tried to pick it up and you got it close to where the desks were, it'd start to make lines on it wherever you moved it.  You wasn't touching it.  And I'm sitting back, okay, this doesn't make sense.  There's nothing between my hand and what I was referring to as the desktop.  But it's doing this.  And it's all because of a little container over to the side when you touched it and brought your hand down.  And, of course, I had to be shown to do this.  What do you think of this, Tony?  Hey, that's cool.  I wonder if I can get one for my room.  But the whole situation is we didn't know what it was all about.  Now, it didn't stay, but when we brought in like a parchment, we felt, okay, this was the paper they used.  When we brought that in and brought it over, then it actually made lines on it.  You could actually write something on it.  Without a pen in hand, just like, you know, you brought your hand across, whatever this was, but then they could go ahead and I figured, okay, they took a finger, they could write in their own language.
Sarge, when you walked onto this craft, did you experience any physical anomalies?

There were times you experienced things.  For example, you would feel like when you go from a low elevation to a higher elevation, you would have like your ears pop.  You would feel like there was a heavy pressure on you from time to time.  And you would experience this when you went from compartment to compartment.  And how do I explain that?  I don't know.
Each compartment's interdimensional.

Absolutely.  And also, it created its own atmosphere.  And at times, you might feel you've been on the craft for only a couple minutes, get out and find out that maybe an hour or two had passed.  And I don't know how to explain that.  Now, did somebody in the team know what that was all about?  I'm quite sure that the guy I always called the colonel and his associates, they knew, but they never felt that it's necessary to explain it to us.  They'd just tell us, you know, you're dealing with a different reality.  That's all you need to know.
